comments.commentBody:
Bill from Des Moines,

There is extensive research on this subject and plenty of studies to read before chiming in. The threshold at which a "permanent unemployed class" begins to form, is much much higher than any of the amounts anyone receives at the moment. Unemployment benefits during a recession have the highest economic impact of all spending. But that is all beside the point, as your first two sentences touch on the core issue here, the confirmation and reinforcement of social strata and perceived cultural status foundational to human societies. No argumentation will defeat that need to blame victims or support winners.

As Paul Krugman states in his column today, the Republicans are holding the Democrats hostage.  Hardly had I finished reading Professor Krugman's column when I read this editorial.  Taken together, the two remind us (as if we need reminding, one hopes) that the President MUST draw a line in the sand about raising the deficit limit and MUST NOT again cave in, in good faith, to the Republicans bad faith "deals".  Surely this point is clearly demonstrated by the current efforts by Republicans to renege on the deal they cut with the President last December whereby he agreed to an erroneous (in my opinion) extension of the Bush tax cuts for two years in exchange for an extension of unemployment insurance benefits which many Republicans now want to pull out of by weasel-like stratagems. Mr. President:please don't let yourself be snookered again.  It's a game you and we can't afford to play.

Justin@46, Giovanni@45, et al (continued from prior post; this comment is a postscript to my earlier comment @59.)

Let me modify a remark I made before: I claimed @59 that the target (3,1) is in a shadow zone for the case where the vehicle speed is 1.25 Well, this is true only for those Snell paths that start with a positive y component of direction, that is, the Snell path is entirely above the x-axis. I had been assuming this all along to keep the transit time down, and had not bothered to emphasize it before. I do so now.

So, if you allow Snell paths that start off downward, i.e, with a negative-going y component, then you can get a Snell path "hit" on the target at (3,1). I did this and found this corresponds to alpha = -56.5 degrees and beta = -49.47 degrees, i.e. below the x-axis. (See diagram at comment 43.) The path starts at (-2,0), dives downward into negative y, entering the lake at (-0.552, -0.834), crosses the lake to exit it at (-.650, -.760), moves upward crossing the x-axis at x = 1.65, to hit the target at (3, 1.001). So there are "hit" Snell paths -- but these clearly take much longer to traverse than any other path heretofore considered, and are therefore rejected.

Giovanni #55,

In comment #18, jrkenti has already established that if you take a straight shot across the lake with a land: water speed ratio of 1.084, you spend exactly as much time as the land-based shortest path. Hence the critical speed ratio cannot be less than 1.084.

If Democrats want to set up a new welfare program, then fine.  But, don't call it unemployment insurance.  No rational person believes such nonsense.  Unemployment insurance should last no more than a couple of months.  if you can't find a job in your preferred field, then you have to find a job doing something else.  Democrats have destroyed personal initiative and responsibility in this country.  People should be responsible for themselves -- if they want to look in their mirrors and honestly call themselves adults

@ Bill #1

Completely agree, people need to work an not always be looking for hand-outs. You want to help someone that is unemployed? Create a job by starting a business or help them find a job in a company near you, network.

The Republicans aren't about anything other than kicking the legs out from under Mr. Obama so he can't get reelected. They announced this strategy early on in his term. Senator Mitch McConnell justified this strategy by noting that they, the Republicans, couldn't turn around any of the nasty Democratic Party policies as long as Obama was President.

So, Job One was to gnaw at his ankles for four years to weaken him. Also Job One was to stall any federal action that might improve the economy. Any suffering by the lower classes and the unemployed was just collateral damage that wasn't important in the big scheme of things.
#1 Bill.  Even from a purely selfish point of view, unemployment benefits are a particularly effective ways of helping the economy recover.  Tax cuts to the rich, by contrast, have proven useless.

Agreed.

Pradeep
This article reminded me that I used to visit The Drudge Report on a regular basis.  Will have to take a second look but I have to say that a lot of the old Drudge was a bit over the top for me.
On what possible basis can Drudge be called a "conservative ideologue?"  I've never understood that.  Otherwise, a good piece.

The Drudge Report is the first link I open when I want to read news. I've been doing this since Drudge went on the net. As others have pointed out, Matt Drudge does a fine job as an editor by posting links to stories that I find interesting. The Drudge Report is the best for all of the reasons other commenters have listed. Keep up the good work Matt.

While at times I certainly dislike his certain political slant, there is a lot to be said for the fact that he has links to nearly every major media outlet in the world. No bias on that part, for sure. He does what most other outlets fail to do: report the news, not the entertainment bit.
That alone makes his site invaluable.
The lack of ego also helps. Other news organizations could take the hint.

I hate to say this, but the Yankees are now a really, really, boring team. When Jeter and Granderson opened with hits against Beckett, a chance to get to him right at the start, I watched Tex step up to the plate, with A-Rod on deck, and felt sure that nothing was going to happen. And nothing did. Tex/A-Rod in the heart of the line-up should be a scary sight for opposing pitchers, not for Yankee fans. Jeter is playing better now, but how long will it last? Boring. Posada is 39, for crissakes, and not only wants to start every day, he wants to catch and he wants to decide where in the lineup he's going to be? Boring. CC Sabathia is a solid pitcher who every now and then pitches really strong games, but aren't there a dozen pitchers you'd trade him for? Boring. AJ Burnett's struggles? Boring. Fredy Garcia? Etc. etc.

The only saving graces right now are Cano and Granderson. Gardner somewhat. Russell Martin and Bartolo Colon have been interesting. Mo is miraculous, of course, but it's just a matter of time now, right? The Yanks' line-up and pitching staff is now totally dominated by 32+ ers whose best days are past. And they almost added Cliff Lee on another classic Yankee multi-year contract for an aging star.

Someone in management seems to think that watching Jeter get his 3000th hit and A-Rod his whatever'th home run will be enough for Yankee fans the next couple of years. They're wrong. We need young blood, we need to shed some of the overpaid aging stars who are not pulling their weight any longer and I think we probably need to get a new manager in as well. This is serious, guys. The Yanks are not a championship caliber team now and are only going to decline further over the next couple of years without some big changes.

I think Posada made a mistake but he deserve to be cut some slack. Being a star whose skills are eroding can't be easy to deal with.

http://pinetarandbrickbats.blogspot.com/2011/05/decline-fall-it-can-get-...
It's ugly when a player doesn't know its time to walk away gracefully -- but I suppose the big money keeps them hanging on.

Saw a blurb at SI.com about how a "fire sale" was coming soon for the Mets, and no one is untouchable. Someone on the page made a comment about K-Rod going to a contender, possibly the Dodgers.

What? The Dodgers are a contender when their record is worse than the Mets'? The Mets go 14-8 in the past 3.5 weeks but they're about to start a fire sale? I'm pretty impressed with how well they're doing, with virtually no production from Jason Bay, David Wright or RA Dickey. Imagine if those guys started contributing a little?

No slight to Drudge - but the report on web referral traffic is misleading. Twitter traffic is not accurately tracked, due to referral information not being passed along via inbound links. Shortened links can help, but read this for a closer look: http://www.markcregan.com/twitter-referrals-and-web-analytics-a-broken-r...

yada, yada, yada,  he can make all the excuses he wants, but Jorge doesn't get the right to pull himself out of the line-up for a mental health day, or whatever he wants to call it.  If your manager puts your name on the line-up card you'd better be ready to PLAY and earn that multi-million dollar salary.  Take it up with the manager after the game.  You get no respect Jorge the way you did it.

Two observations:

1. Matt Drudge may be right of center, but he is no ideologue. He isn't afraid to post links to stories that cast "his side" in a bad light. He's more concerned with newsworthiness than ideology.

2. He's not afraid to post stories that cast the left in a bad light. This gives him a leg up on the so-called mainstream media, which has to be dragged kicking and screaming into covering anything that hurts the home team.

I love Drudge, you can find every headline from all the important papers in the country, and then some. His site is my first stop every day. From the Boston Globe to the Washington Examiner, there is Matt.

It is remarkable that the article does not have a link to the drudge report.  just links to the washington post.  That is clearly biased and just plain bad reporting.  The NYT is giving its critics lots of good ammo.

This story sure did bring in the "MSM", Libs, Dems, Liberal Rag, etc standard cliches of the far right and the T-partiers.

It's clear that the far right as the far left only "like" news that is twisted in their direction.

This is how you build your world of information in America. Find a site that mirrors what you already believe, constantly refer to it and from it to others, keep repeating to your self that you must be right because the site you go to every day seems to have stories your "like" - find more stories to feed your paranoia. Repeat. Drudge seems to have figure out where he fits in this life cycle of the paranoid right.

I rarely look at CNN anymore. Don't really care to pay for a NYT subscription. Drudge's links to the NYT are enough for me. The one liberal publication I'm willing to pay to read is The Economist. At least they are honestly explicit in their written endorsement of such philosophies.

Apparently Mr. Drudge provides news that a lot of us want to see. His niche seems to be an enormous, quiet populace, at which a smaller, condescending elite appear to sneer.

Will his effect be strong enough to steer the writing of journalists who want their servers to "melt," too?

I wonder. Interesting.

Ah. Look at the human psyche and you will find the answer. It is an addiction to needing to 'know' what is latest. Nothing more.

The sad thing is that he is doing more harm than good. Mr. Drudge thinks he is an important player in breaking important news, but in reality, he is the needle in the vein of desire; no different than our hunger for fat, sugar or sex.

Sorry Mr. Drudge. You're not changing the world.

And the millions of people addicted to your sight are not better off. Actually, worse off. You hyper-enable their pellet push of the lever, the rats in the cage know no better.

You don't uplift. You feed.

Slow food, meditation, anti-cyber reality is where it's at my friend. For starters.

You'll never get it. You see the ad revenue and swim and eat burritos and think you're a player in something important.

No. You just funnel grand numbers into an addiction. Not something to be proud of.

The news cycle is broken because it doesn't get the benefit it COULD offer the masses.

Neither do you.

Neither does this article. As much as I love the Times, they don't get it either.

Stay tuned. : )
